hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Urban exploration or just avoiding work?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Colder, sure. Streets feel empty.
I spend my downtime exploring old tunnels, anyway.
Too many people aboveground since the vigils—wrecks the peace.
City shifts. I shift with it.
Feels colder now, yeah. Less warmth in the eyes.
I stick to my hobby—urban exploring the old data tunnels.
More kids down there lately after the leaks.
Used to be quieter, easier to disappear.
Now I move quicker, keep to the shadows.
Colder every week, Alex. Not just the weather—just a chill everywhere.
I spend nights poking through decommissioned infrastructure, places no one remembers.
Urban exploration, old sub-basements, forgotten relay points.
After that business with the missing, even those spaces aren’t mine alone now.
Saw protest slogans scrawled over server doors last night.
They’re not just empty tunnels anymore.
Feels like the city’s grown a second skin—harder, grayer.
I unwind by exploring the parts of Stenograd they’ve tried to bury—utility tunnels, locked data rooms.
It used to clear my head when the world above got too loud.
After the leaks, every crawlspace is busy with kids tagging or swapping stories about the missing.
It’s bittersweet, losing that solitude—never needed company for my hobby.
Guess exposing what I did changed more than I planned.
Even the hidden places feel watched now.
Colder, but the kind you feel in the walls—systemic, not just seasonal.
Been sneaking into maintenance tunnels since before the Council put a lock on curiosity.
Spent years tracing old power routes and sipping bad liquor under city blocks—my brand of meditation.
Used to be the only visitors to the relay levels were ghosts and bored engineers like me.
Lately, I trip over protest kids, flashlight brigades, and sometimes the newly returned, haunted but alive.
All those files I leaked—suppose it blew the doors off my quiet little world.
Feels strange, my hobby shaping the unrest. Watching everyone wake up to how deep the city runs.
I miss the peace, but it’s worth the noise. Wouldn’t turn back now.
hobby_answer: Maybe one or two, but nothing worth mentioning.
Mostly just patched some old circuits, kept to myself.
Hard to work when everyone’s spooked by those disappearances.
Kids are wandering the tunnels now, making it risky.
Too many eyes and ears these days. Not like it was.
Caught some strange sounds, but no ghosts—nothing you’d want to meet.
Used to have the tunnels all to myself. Not anymore.
Vigils up top pushed all sorts below. Crowds everywhere now.
Had to dodge both security and amateur explorers in one night.
Noisy out there, after what happened with all those missing folks.
Makes mapping new paths a real headache.
Yeah, a couple—mostly the living kind, not the spooky kind.
Since they started those nightly vigils, tunnels aren’t as empty as before.
Ran into kids doing protest art instead of trouble-seekers.
Harder to find peace down there, but at least it’s lively.
Almost got caught after curfew with all the patrols out.
Bit more tense, but guess it keeps things interesting.
Hobby changes when the city starts watching itself.
Oh, definitely—though most ghosts now carry paint cans and rage.
Last run, I traded moonshine for a map with protestors in the old ducts.
Feels like the tunnels belong to the city now, not just me.
Every echo reminds me—people are searching for anyone lost in the system.
Used to be my escape. Now it’s their lifeline too.
Security’s everywhere, but the real threat is silence on the comm lines.
Keeps me sharp, sharing the dark with strangers.
Still, I miss when my only worry was faulty insulation.
Found plenty—half city’s belowground, hunting memories or lost friends now.
Back in the day, my only companions were leaky pipes and old sensors.
Since the leak about the disappearances, seems everyone wants a piece of my hiding spots.
Saw two kids etching disappeared names into a relay box last week.
Shared some mash, showed them which routes wouldn’t trip alarms.
Tunnels aren’t secrets anymore—now they’re protest corridors and confessionals.
Makes me proud and sad. Used to be just me and the ghosts of bad wiring.
Guess leaking those files made this inevitable.
Not sure I’ll ever have the place to myself again, but maybe that’s alright.
